metadata.title: Introducing two new Classes of Numbers, Partial-Undetermined pU and Undetermined U.
metadata.description: In questo contributo vengono introdotte due nuove classi numeriche, i numeri parzialmente indeterminati p𝕌, e i numeri indeterminati 𝕌. I numeri p𝕌 sono costituiti da un’alternanza di lettere e cifre (alfanumerici), del tipo “X9M.Y76”, dove le lettere (maiuscole) rappresentano le “variabili posizionali”. I numeri 𝕌 sono invece interamente costituiti da lettere, come “RTG.H”. Quando un numero indeterminato 𝕌 è totalmente non vincolato, esso prende il nome di “variabile indefinita”. Una viariabile indefinita viene rappresentata con una lettera minuscola (es. ). L’insieme di tutte le variabili indefinite, numeri dei quali non si conosce né la struttura, tantomeno la classe di appartenenza, forma l’insieme 𝕍. Assegnando una classe di appartenenza, come condizione a contorno, alla variabile indefinita (es. ), otteniamo una “variabile vincolata” o “definita per classe”. L’insieme di tutte le variabili vincolate di una determinata classe viene indicato dalla lettera 𝕍, seguita da quella della classe di appartenenza (es. , etc..). L'insieme 𝕍 ha come sott’insieme 𝕌, e questo a sua volta p𝕌, e così via, fino ai numeri naturali . Perciò i numeri p𝕌 e 𝕌 formano un collegamento naturale tra le variabili indefinite 𝕍, e le altre classi numeriche,  e di conseguenza tra l’algebra astratta e quella numerica. Le applicazioni di tali numeri spaziano dall’analisi numerica al calcolo simbolico, dalla fisica teorica e computazionale, alla matematica dei tensori e delle algebre superiori, fino all’informatica, crittografia, intelligenza artificiale, e modellistica economica, aprendo la strada a una nuova branca della matematica, in grado di unificare calcolo numerico, algebra simbolica e probabilità in un quadro coerente e universale.
references: [1]	Berenstein, A., & Zelevinsky, A. (2001). Tensor product multiplicities, canonical bases and totally positive varieties. Inventiones mathematicae, *143*(1), 77-128.

[2]	Deutsch, D. (1985). Quantum theory, the Church–Turing principle and the universal quantum computer. Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. A. Mathematical and Physical Sciences, *400*(1818), 97–117.
[3]	Falconer, K. (2003). Fractal geometry: Mathematical foundations and applications (2nd ed.). John Wiley & Sons.
[4]	Halpern, J. Y. (2003). Reasoning about uncertainty. The MIT Press.
[5]	Hickey, T., Ju, Q., & Van Emden, M. H. (2001). Interval Arithmetic: From Principles to Implementation. Journal of the ACM, *48*(5), 1038–1068.

[6]	Jaeger, M. (2005). Probabilistic decision graphs—combining verification and AI techniques for probabilistic inference. International Journal of Uncertainty, Fuzziness and Knowledge-Based Systems, *12*(S01), 19-42.
[7]	Mandelbrot, B. B. (1982). The fractal geometry of nature. W. H. Freeman.
[8]	Moore, R. E., Kearfott, R. B., & Cloud, M. J. (2009). Introduction to interval analysis. Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics.
[9]	 Nielsen, M. A., & Chuang, I. L. (2010). Quantum computation and quantum information: 10th anniversary edition. Cambridge University Press.
[10]	 Shafer, G. (1976). A mathematical theory of evidence. Princeton University Press.
[11]	 Shor, P. W. (1994). Algorithms for quantum computation: discrete logarithms and factoring. In Proceedings of the 35th Annual Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (pp. 124-134). IEEE.
[12]	 Zadeh, L. A. (1965). Fuzzy sets. Information and Control, *8*(3), 338–353.
[13]	 Gierz, G., Hofmann, K. H., Keimel, K., Lawson, J. D., Mislove, M., & Scott, D. S. (2003). Continuous lattices and domains. Cambridge University Press.
[14]	 Mackey, G. W. (1963). The mathematical foundations of quantum mechanics.
[15]	 Nguyen, H. T., Kreinovich, V., & Wu, B. (1997). Fuzzy/probabilistic arithmetic and its applications to intelligent systems. In Proceedings of the 1997  (pp. 441-445). IEEE.

metadata.title: IODP Expedition 317 Section-half images
metadata.description: Digital section images were taken of the flat face of split cores on the Section Half Imaging Logger (SHIL) using a linescan camera at a resolution of 20 lines/mm (50 micron pixels). Cores were imaged as soon as possible after splitting to minimize color changes that occur through oxidation and drying. The SHIL produces TIF files as well as reduced-size JPG files. The TIF files are not kept online but users may request them from the IODP-JRSO Data Librarian.

grants.title: System Integration Contractor for the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program

metadata.title: IODP Expedition 317 Natural gamma radiation
metadata.description: Natural gamma radiation (NGR) data in the ~0.1 to 3.0 MeV range were measured using eight custom-designed sodium iodide (thallium) [NaI(Tl)] detectors arranged along the core measurement axis at 20 cm intervals. The NGR system uses layers of passive shielding (lead) and active shielding (plastic scintillators and coincidence electronics) to reduce the cosmic-ray signal for low-count analysis of sediment core sections and to obtain the maximum signal-to-noise ratio. Data are reported on a total counts per second basis and the raw spectral files are available as compressed files for later analysis.

grants.title: System Integration Contractor for the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program

metadata.title: IODP Expedition 317 Core orientation
metadata.description: Core orientation data were measured downhole during advanced piston corer (APC) coring, either by Minex FlexIT or Icefield MI-5 core orientation tool. These tools measure magnetic strength and orientation, 3-axis accelerometer data, and tool temperature data.

grants.title: System Integration Contractor for the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program

metadata.title: IODP Expedition 317 P-wave velocity bayonet (section)
metadata.description: P-wave velocity data were measured on undisturbed section halves using pairs of piezoelectric transducers mounted in bayonets that are inserted into soft sediment along the JRSO-defined y-axis and/or z-axis. Report includes P-wave velocity in y and/or z direction, bayonet separation, traveltime between transducers, and first arrival picks.

grants.title: System Integration Contractor for the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program

metadata.title: IODP Expedition 317 Salinity
metadata.description: Salinity was measured on interstitial water (IW) samples using an optical refractometer.

grants.title: System Integration Contractor for the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program

metadata.title: IODP Expedition 317 Sample report
metadata.description: Report includes detailed information about samples taken for testing: location/depth, type/form factor, test, request number, and database identifier.

grants.title: System Integration Contractor for the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program

metadata.title: IODP Expedition 317 Section summary
metadata.description: Report includes data for individual core sections: coring/drilling depths and recovery, database identifiers for the whole section and section halves, and number of samples taken from the section before and after splitting.

grants.title: System Integration Contractor for the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program

metadata.title: IODP Expedition 317 Source rock analyzer (SRA)
metadata.description: SRA is run for the purpose of safety monitoring and yields information about thermal maturation and source of hydrocarbons, as well as petroleum potential, in the sediment or rocks at a drilled site. Samples are heated in a pyrolysis oven in an inert atmosphere to quantitatively and selectively determine free hydrocarbons contained in the sample and the hydrogen- and oxygen-containing compounds that are volatilized during the cracking of unextractable organic matter in the sample (kerogen).

grants.title: System Integration Contractor for the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program

metadata.title: IODP Expedition 317 Magnetic remanence (SRM-discrete)
metadata.description: Raw data files for the magnetic remanence measurements of discrete and section-half samples on the superconducting rock magnetometer (SRM-DISC and SRM-SECT) are stored on by hole and by expedition, and are designated as discrete samples, section halves, or, rarely, whole-round sections.

grants.title: System Integration Contractor for the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program
